Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Shape and stickiness: how dust cluster properties affect the evolution of the Universe

POR.DRECONTENT:
Understanding how the Universe went from a dark cloud of hydrogen and helium to the lively place it is now, with galaxies, stars, and all the elements that allow for the development of life, is one of the major challenges of modern astrophysics. Among the various riddles are the mechanisms that led to the formation of dust particles, and the location of where the first grains condensed. Within the astrophysics community it is believed that cosmic dust forms by the process of nucleation. For the purposes of this project, nucleation is the spontaneous phase change of atoms, or molecules, in a gaseous state to a cluster, or grain, of them in a solid state. Much of the previous work in dust nucleation focuses on using a classical thermodynamic nucleation approach which assumes that grains nucleate and grow as spheres. Once a grain has nucleated, it grows through the adhesion of atoms, or molecules, on the grain surface. This project aims at studying the role of early supernova explosions as dust factories, deepening our understanding of the physics of dust nucleation.

In previous work it has been assumed that an atom or molecule that contacts a grain will always stick to the grain. Once it is known how grains nucleate and grow, one can calculate the total mass of material contained in grains if given sufficient initial conditions information. The use of the classical nucleation theory, with the inclusion of the above assumptions, however, has tended to over-predict, when compared to observations, the total mass of dust grains produced after, say, a supernova explosion. It is therefore important to consider the effects of different shapes of nucleating grains and the likelihood of an atom or molecule sticking to the grain, in an effort to more closely align prediction and observation. In this work be begin to investigate the affects the shape and stickiness of the grain have on the nucleation rate.

The results from this suggest that when grains are not spherical nor completely sticky, the nucleation rate is reduced. Thus, sticky, spherical grains have the highest nucleation rate, and from our results, the less spherical the grain, the lower the nucleation rate. A reduction in the stickiness will also result in a reduction of the nucleation rate. The results from this project, however, are only applicable for one point in time and cannot describe how the nucleation rate will change as the density of the gaseous phase of atoms or molecules decreases over time.
